Port Lighting. / In further reference to my letter herein, of 15th March, (23rd Ramdhaan)last, I would report that I have had a further opportunity of discussing this question with navigating officers, and I would amend my letter as follows: A. The approach to the Port. A stone beacon having recently been erected on the Fesht al Djebal, if a permanent light were affixed upon this beacon, with a range of at least twentymiles, there would be no need to remove the present outer buoy light, as suggested. It will be remembered that the danger in navigating this port lies in the approach to the Outer Buoy, owing to the reefs and submerged rocks in that approach. After the Outer Buoy is found, all danger is past; and the purpose of a light on the Fesht al Djebal is to warn mariners of the situa tion of the Fesht, and to assist them in avoiding the Fesht and find^the Outer Buoy light. It is essential that the light should have a range of at least twenty miles, to te effective. Such a fixed light would eliminate the necessity for a bright anchored light, which is liable to the risk of^drifty B. The Lighting of the Port . In proceeding to anchorage, (after having passed the Outer Buoy) steamers proceed upon a course laid upon the Jebbal Lukkan and the Western Minaret of the Mosque of the Suq al Khamis. A reasonably bright light placed upon this western minaret, which is high, would render a light upon the Portuguese Fort unnecessary, and a steamer, after sunset, could proceed along its usual course to anchorage with safety, which at present it is unable to do. This light, with the Customs Light and the Maharaq light would meet the requirements of Uavigators desiring to make the port at night; and the three lights would form the 'triangle' which I recommend. In general, I would report that navigators regard this port in view of its importance, as the worst-lighted in the Persian Gulf. I have the honour'to be. Sir, Your Most Obedient Servant,

titleInfo.title: 'File 8/10 Lighting and buoying in the Gulf'

physicalDescription.extent: The contents of the file are arranged in rough chronological order, from the earliest at the front to the latest at the rear.
Foliation: Foliation starts on the front cover and continues to end of the file. Foliation is in circled pencil numbers in the top-right corner of each recto.

mods.abstract: The file contains correspondence related to proposals for the installation of lighting and bouys at various ports on the Arab coast of the Gulf (Bahrain, Muscat and Kuwait).
